document.title: Regulated functions and the regulated integral

para.p:

= I
[ a , b ]
and let
X
be a normed space. A function

∈ t

→ s

para.p: We prove in the following theorem that the set of regulated functions from a compact interval to a Banach space is itself a Banach space.

The following lemma shows that the set of points of discontinuity of a regulated function taking values in a Banach space is countable.

Since
> ϵ 0

Math.text: (norm@((integral _ I)@(f) - (integral _ I _ 1)@(f _ 1) - (integral _ I _ 2)@(f _ 2))) _ infinity = 0

para.p: so

Math.text: (integral _ I)@(f) = (integral _ I _ 1)@(f _ 1) + (integral _ I _ 2)@(f _ 2)

para.p: proving the claim. ∎
We prove that applying a bounded linear map and taking the regulated integral commute. 2 2 footnote 2 Jean-Paul Penot, Calculus Without Derivatives, p. 124, Proposition 2.18.

para.p: Using this,

Math.text: norm@((integral _ I)@(T compose f) - T * (integral _ I)@(f)) less= norm@((integral _ I)@(T compose f) - (integral _ I)@(T compose g)) + norm@((integral _ I)@(T compose g) - T * (integral _ I)@(g)) + norm@(T * (integral _ I)@(g) - T * (integral _ I)@(f)) = norm@((integral _ I)@(T compose (f - g))) + norm@(T * (integral _ I)@(f - g)) less= (b - a) * (norm@(T compose (f - g))) _ infinity + norm@(T) * norm@((integral _ I)@(f - g)) less= (b - a) * norm@(T) * (norm@(f - g)) _ infinity + conditional@(norm@(T) * (b - a) * (norm@(f - g)) _ infinity * bra@(2 * (b - a)) * T, epsilon)
norm@((integral _ I)@(T compose f) - T * (integral _ I)@(f))
norm@((integral _ I)@(T compose f) - (integral _ I)@(T compose g)) + norm@((integral _ I)@(T compose g) - T * (integral _ I)@(g))
+ norm@(T * (integral _ I)@(g) - T * (integral _ I)@(f))
norm@((integral _ I)@(T compose (f - g))) + norm@(T * (integral _ I)@(f - g))
(b - a) * (norm@(T compose (f - g))) _ infinity + norm@(T) * norm@((integral _ I)@(f - g))
(b - a) * norm@(T) * (norm@(f - g)) _ infinity + norm@(T) * (b - a) * (norm@(f - g)) _ infinity
2 * (b - a) * norm@(T) * epsilon

The following is the mean value theorem for functions taking values in a Banach space. 3 3 footnote 3 Henri Cartan, Differential Calculus, p. 39, Theorem 3.1.3.

0 < η < r
, using Lemma we have

Math.text: norm@(((integral _ a) ^ (t + r))@(f) - ((integral _ a) ^ t)@(f) - ((integral _ t) ^ (t + r))@(f * t ^ +)) = norm@(((integral _ t) ^ (t + r))@(f) - ((integral _ t) ^ (t + r))@(f * t ^ +)) = norm@(((integral _ t) ^ (t + eta))@(f - f * t ^ +) + ((integral _ (t + eta)) ^ (t + r))@(f - f * t ^ +)) less= eta * (supremum _ (t less= s less= t + eta))@(norm@(f * s - f * t ^ +)) + (r - eta) * (supremum _ (t + eta less= s less= t + r))@(norm@(f * s - f * t ^ +)) less= 2 * (norm@(f)) _ infinity * eta + (r - eta) * epsilon
norm@(((integral _ a) ^ (t + r))@(f) - ((integral _ a) ^ t)@(f) - ((integral _ t) ^ (t + r))@(f * t ^ +))
norm@(((integral _ t) ^ (t + r))@(f) - ((integral _ t) ^ (t + r))@(f * t ^ +))
norm@(((integral _ t) ^ (t + eta))@(f - f * t ^ +) + ((integral _ (t + eta)) ^ (t + r))@(f - f * t ^ +))
eta * (supremum _ (t less= s less= t + eta))@(norm@(f * s - f * t ^ +))
+ (r - eta) * (supremum _ (t + eta less= s less= t + r))@(norm@(f * s - f * t ^ +))
2 * (norm@(f)) _ infinity * eta + (r - eta) * epsilon

para.p:
This is true for all
0 < η < r
, so

Math.text: norm@(((integral _ a) ^ (t + r))@(f) - ((integral _ a) ^ t)@(f) - ((integral _ t) ^ (t + r))@(f * t ^ +)) less= r * epsilon

para.p: i.e.

Math.text: norm@((g * (t + r) - g * t) / r - f * t ^ +) less= epsilon

para.p: This shows that

Math.text: (g _ +) ^ prime * t = f * t ^ +

para.p: Similarly,

Math.text: (g _ -) ^ prime * t = f * t ^ -

Math.text: norm@(g * s - g * t) = norm@(((integral _ a) ^ s)@(f) - ((integral _ a) ^ t)@(f)) = norm@(((integral _ s) ^ t)@(f)) less= evaluated-at@(absolute-value@(t - s) * (norm@(f)) _ infinity * bra@(delta) * f, infinity) = epsilon

para.p:

Suppose that
X

: f

: h

. Because

: g

defined by
=
⁢ g

f

on
[ a , b ]
. Then applying Lemma , there is some
∈ c X

=

⁢ f

c
for all

[ a , b ]

. Hence, for all

[ a , b ]
,

Math.text: f * t = f * a + ((integral _ a) ^ t)@(h)

para.p: But

Math.text: ((integral _ a) ^ t)@(h) = ((integral _ a) ^ (a + eta _ 1))@(h) + ((integral _ (a + eta _ 1)) ^ (t - eta _ 2))@(h) + ((integral _ (t - eta _ 2)) ^ t)@(h) = ((integral _ a) ^ (a + eta _ 1))@(h) + ((integral _ (a + eta _ 1)) ^ (t - eta _ 2))@(f ^ prime) + ((integral _ (t - eta _ 2)) ^ t)@(h)

para.p: and

Math.text: formulae@(norm@(((integral _ a) ^ (a + eta _ 1))@(h)) less= eta _ 1 * (norm@(h)) _ infinity, norm@(((integral _ (t - eta _ 2)) ^ t)@(h)) less= eta _ 2 * (norm@(h)) _ infinity)

para.p:
hence as
→
η 1

and
→

0 +
,

Math.text: ((integral _ (a + eta _ 1)) ^ (t - eta _ 2))@(f ^ prime) to ((integral _ a) ^ t)@(h)

para.p: and so it makes sense to write

Math.text: ((integral _ a) ^ t)@(f ^ prime) = ((integral _ a) ^ t)@(h)

para.p:
and thus for all
∈ t
[ a , b ]
,

Math.text: f * t = f * a + ((integral _ a) ^ t)@(f ^ prime)
